annotation.TEXT: First off: The only way you can damage the Wily Capsule is in the most basic way possible. You can't use any extra weapons, nor can you charge your buster. You're stuck picking away it this boss one buster pellet at a time (it also doesn't help that he has a much larger health-bar than usual). I get that you're riding Rush, and that you couldn't use weapons on him in the original series, but it's still no excuse to drag this fight out longer than it needs to be.

Yeah, I couldn't resist using that clip. Regardless, it still begs the question: Why don't the projectiles or holograms despawn when the boss is beaten? Or better yet, why not have the spikes disappear to prevent that from happening? If the same kind of fail-safe was implemented with the Dragon boss, why not this one?

This phase happens to be weak to the Cipher Decode. In theory, this weapon would be helpful since it lingers while hitting things, but half the time I can't help but notice that it passes right through these weak points (even when they're open to attack). I don't know if it's just the Cipher Decode itself or if the hit-box for the weak points is messed up, but it gets to be an issue as the fight goes on (especially since the invulnerability rate speeds up so much that it practically comes down to luck in whether or not you land a hit).

Oh god...and no shield weapon, either. Thankfully, the crystal shards seem to have a very long cool-down period before starting back up again. Regardless, it's still a good idea to take your time in this section (and be prepared to deal with a rather dickish enemy placement in one instance).

As per usual, I'm skipping the boss refights. However, it's interesting to note that the two bosses you fight between these sections are randomized into sets of four. This makes it so that you won't know who you're fighting until you step into the boss pod (while it's certainly an interesting deviation from the usual refights, I still find the whole process to be a bit redundant).

Note: Don't slide here. I know it looks like it would work, but you'll actually end up getting instant-killed when you reach the edge. Why this is, I have no idea (but I'm going to guess it's due to the way the crushers are programmed).

Yes, a good portion of this stage's layout is ripped directly from the official games, spanning all the way from MM1 to 10. There are a few differences here and there with the stage mock-ups, though as mentioned before, most of them are from mechanical aspects more than anything.

In any case, this is where I would normally give my overall thoughts on the game during the credits...but to be honest, I actually had to cut them out from this recording (mostly because this video would have pushed close to being about 30 minutes if I had kept them in). As such, all of my primary thoughts on this game are in the description this time around.

Of course, that's not the end of it. We now come to the absolute worst part of the game: The real final boss. I almost don't even know where to begin describing it, considering how many broken mechanics are on display here.

Franken-Wily here serves as our final boss, but for half-assed purposes, I'll just refer to him as "Jay Leno." Jay has a few problems concerning his overall mechanics: mainly in that to damage him, you need to hit the glowing areas on his shoulders (which periodically switch to being briefly invulnerable). That's all fine and dandy, but there are several problems getting in the way of this. First, he tends to shake the ground on a near-constant basis, which prevents you from jumping (and in turn, ruining any opportunities to hit a weak spot).
Honestly, if you don't want to see the rest of this fight (trust me, you're not missing much), skip to 14:20 for the ending.

Whatever the case may be, it's time to finish this whole thing up (though I'm not going into the end without a bit of life insurance, so to speak). Wily 5 is predictably short, though it isn't exactly a straight run-through to the last boss. It's not terribly difficult, though there are a few instances of annoying yoku block puzzles along the way (both of which are located over instant death).

After escaping the hell of Wily 3, it's time to deal with the final two stages of the game. Wily 4 isn't quite as bad as the last stage, but it certainly has its moments. The overall layout is more of a "novelty" than anything, though I wouldn't exactly mind that if not for some of the mechanics in certain areas...
Besides, if I had let the video run on for that long, I wouldn't have time for something extra I wanted to show at the end here...

The Bass Saber itself seem to deal a bit more damage than the regular charged shots, but much like the rest of this game, it isn't without its issues. You can't produce these saber slashes while in the air (doing so only produces a charged shot). It also doesn't seem to work while you're on the rail-sections in Primal Man's stage and Wily 3 (however, this glitch has since been fixed in recent updates).

Completing the game while obtaining Beat during your playthrough will unlock one of 9 secrets (there's also a 10th secret you get for collecting all the artwork). You can adjust these when you begin a new game, turning each one on or off. The first secret you'll get is the Bass Saber, which is somewhat of a replacement for your charged shots.

Thank goodness that fight is over with. Anyways, as one final note on this ending: I initially heard that to get the "true ending" to this game, you needed to unlock Beat and collect all the artwork item drops from enemies. I actually beat this game twice now: The first time while obtaining Beat and all the art, and the second time (the run you just saw) while getting Beat and passing up on most of the art. I can tell you right now: The ending doesn't seem to change based on those aspects.
Finally, Wily himself has a few attacks that make him invincible. Why was this necessary? This fight is already tedious enough as it is, so do we really need it to be drawn out even longer?

Admittedly, the boss of Wily 4 is probably my favorite one in the game. The mechanics are a bit strange at first, but it's definitely one of the better boss fights this game has to offer (even if it is one of the easier ones). With that being said however, it's not without its issues...as you'll see at the end of the fight.

Just to note: You can't control how high you go while on these springs. Mega Man will always be propelled to a set height from them. While this does simplify things in terms of judging when you need to move to the next platform, it makes dealing with the Telly enemies in this section far more annoying than usual.

The real kicker of this fight is that it changes the rules for your recoil after getting hit. Your knock-back now lasts even longer than usual, which means you have absolutely zero chance to recover if something is lingering over you. You can literally get hit-stunned to death with no way to fight back (especially if Wily decides to use his attack where he bounces around and create projectiles that travel along the borders of the screen).
